series.title: Laravel Authentication (Breeze, Jetstream, Fortify)
series.body:
Laravel offers several options for Authentication in your applications. If you'd prefer a head start, you might reach for one of the available first-party packages that provide robust, modern scaffolding for your authentication layer. For example, Laravel Breeze is an excellent choice to get up and running quickly. If you require additional features, Laravel Jetstream offers two-factor auth, API tokens and team management. If you'd instead prefer to use your own front-end stack, you might consider Laravel Fortify as the backend implementation.

In this series, we'll review how to use and customize these packages in order to fit the authentication needs of your application.
series.strippedBody:
Laravel offers several options for Authentication in your applications. If you'd prefer a head start, you might reach for one of the available first-party packages that provide robust, modern scaffolding for your authentication layer. For example, Laravel Breeze is an excellent choice to get up and running quickly. If you require additional features, Laravel Jetstream offers two-factor auth, API tokens and team management. If you'd instead prefer to use your own front-end stack, you might consider Laravel Fortify as the backend implementation.

 In this series, we'll review how to use and customize these packages in order to fit the authentication needs of your application.

profile.bio: Greetings! I'm Andre, a full-stack web developer and Laracasts instructor. My other hobbies include playing guitar, videography and gaming.

episodes.title: Breeze Overview and Usage
episodes.body: Laravel Breeze is a minimal and simple starting point for your authentication scaffolding in Laravel. It’s the successor to the laravel/ui package and is built using Tailwind CSS, AlpineJS and Blade Components. It publishes everything needed for auth into your project folder, which means it’s easily customizable - and even includes tests.
episodes.excerpt: Laravel Breeze is a minimal and simple starting point for your authentication scaffolding in Laravel. It’s the...

episodes.title: Jetstream Installation and Features
episodes.body:
Laravel Jetstream is a beautifully designed application scaffolding tool that provides a great starting point for your new applications. It’s built with Tailwind CSS, AlpineJS and Blade Components and includes features like login, registration, profile management, two-factor auth, session management, API tokens, and teams.

In this episode, we take a look at all of these features from a user’s point of view.
episodes.excerpt: Laravel Jetstream is a beautifully designed application scaffolding tool that provides a great starting point for your...

episodes.title: Customize Views
episodes.body: Jetstream allows you to publish all views and Blade components to your project folder, making it easy to customize the look and feel of your application. Let's review how.
episodes.excerpt: Jetstream allows you to publish all views and Blade components to your project folder, making it easy...

episodes.title: Customize Routes
episodes.body: Next, we'll have a look at how to publish and customize routes for both Jetstream and Fortify.
episodes.excerpt: Next, we'll have a look at how to publish and customize routes for both Jetstream and Fortify.

episodes.title: Actions
episodes.body: Most of the functionality of Jetstream (and Fortify) can be customized by modifying corresponding Actions. These classes are all available in your project folder. Let's take a look at a few examples in this video.
episodes.excerpt: Most of the functionality of Jetstream (and Fortify) can be customized by modifying corresponding Actions. These classes...

episodes.title: API Tokens
episodes.body: Let's now review Jetstream’s API tokens feature. This is technically a feature of Laravel Sanctum, but Jetstream includes all the necessary frontend views and scaffolding to accomplish this. API Tokens allow you to issue API tokens / personal access tokens that may be used to authenticate API requests to your application.
episodes.excerpt: Let's now review Jetstream’s API tokens feature. This is technically a feature of Laravel Sanctum, but Jetstream...

episodes.title: Team Support
episodes.body: Jetstream has built-in support for teams and team management. Let's have a look at making use of these features to extend a typical blog application to support teams.
episodes.excerpt: Jetstream has built-in support for teams and team management. Let's have a look at making use of...

episodes.title: Inertia Integration
episodes.body: Jetstream provides the option to choose Inertia as your Laravel Stack. Inertia replaces your Blade views and components with Vue components, if you prefer to work with JavaScript. Let's review a handful of examples where we modify pages and components with Vue.
episodes.excerpt: Jetstream provides the option to choose Inertia as your Laravel Stack. Inertia replaces your Blade views and...

episodes.title: Login and Registration
episodes.body: Let's install Fortify into a fresh Laravel application and take a look at creating the necessary front-end Blade views for logging in and registering.
episodes.excerpt: Let's install Fortify into a fresh Laravel application and take a look at creating the necessary front-end...

episodes.title: Email Verification
episodes.body: Let's take a look at verifying a user’s email address after the registration process. We'll also briefly review how to customize the email template.
episodes.excerpt: Let's take a look at verifying a user’s email address after the registration process. We'll also briefly...

episodes.title: Reset Passwords
episodes.body: In this lesson, we'll learn how to allow users to enter their email for a forgotten password, receive an email, and then choose a new password with the reset password form.
episodes.excerpt: In this lesson, we'll learn how to allow users to enter their email for a forgotten password,...

episodes.title: Profile and Password Updates
episodes.body: In this episode, we leverage Fortify to allow users to update their profile details and password.
episodes.excerpt: In this episode, we leverage Fortify to allow users to update their profile details and password.

episodes.title: Password Confirmation
episodes.body: Sometimes you want to confirm a user’s password before performing a particular task. Fortify allows us to do this easily by creating a simple form along with the password.confirm middleware.
episodes.excerpt: Sometimes you want to confirm a user’s password before performing a particular task. Fortify allows us to...

episodes.title: Two-Factor Authentication
episodes.body: Let's take a look at turning on two-factor authentication from within the user’s dashboard. This involves rendering a QR code and generating recovery codes. We also take a look at building the two-factor challenge that requires the user to enter these codes to complete the authentication process.
episodes.excerpt: Let's take a look at turning on two-factor authentication from within the user’s dashboard. This involves rendering...

episodes.title: API Usage
episodes.body: Let's review how to leverage Fortify as an API to power third-party tools, like single-page or mobile apps. Fortify provides support for this and can simplify the entire process.
episodes.excerpt: Let's review how to leverage Fortify as an API to power third-party tools, like single-page or mobile...

episodes.title: SPA Authentication With Sanctum
episodes.body: Let's have a look at using Sanctum in combination with Fortify to authenticate our single-page apps.
episodes.excerpt: Let's have a look at using Sanctum in combination with Fortify to authenticate our single-page apps.

episodes.title: Mobile App Authentication With Sanctum
episodes.body: Let's now use Sanctum to authenticate non-browser-based mobile or desktop applications.
episodes.excerpt: Let's now use Sanctum to authenticate non-browser-based mobile or desktop applications.

episodes.title: Manual Login and Registration
episodes.body: Let's now have a look at performing authentication manually using Laravel's built in authentication features. We'll start off by implementing a typical login and registration system.
episodes.excerpt: Let's now have a look at performing authentication manually using Laravel's built in authentication features. We'll start...

episodes.title: Forgot Password and Reset Password
episodes.body: Next, we can use Laravel's internal PasswordBroker to implement the "Forgot Password" and "Reset Password" features.
episodes.excerpt: Next, we can use Laravel's internal PasswordBroker to implement the "Forgot Password" and "Reset Password" features.

episodes.title: Jetstream Version 2 Upgrade Notes
episodes.body: In this episode, come along as I review some of the new features that were introduced as part of Jetstream Version 2. This will include the terms and privacy policy, team invites, and feature tests.
episodes.excerpt: In this episode, come along as I review some of the new features that were introduced as...

data.body:
Are you planning to update this with Inertia.js integration? I'm trying to make sense of the overall structure but being a beginner, I'm somewhat overwhelmed with the Breeze/Vue/Inertia stacks.

The Laravel installation page recommends Breeze as a starting point rather than Jetstream but it seems like so little is covered here. I plan to make use of the Laravel authentication starter pack and extend the stacks to all of my app.

I did watch your personal YT tutorial on inertia/vue/laravel which has cleared out quite a chunk of my confusion. It would be better if there's a beginner course here for the 'starter packs' offered in Laravel docs.

data.bodyInMarkdown:
Are you planning to update this with Inertia.js integration? I'm trying to make sense of the overall structure but being a beginner, I'm somewhat overwhelmed with the Breeze/Vue/Inertia stacks.

The Laravel installation page recommends Breeze as a starting point rather than Jetstream but it seems like so little is covered here. I plan to make use of the Laravel authentication starter pack and extend the stacks to all of my app.

I did watch your personal YT tutorial on inertia/vue/laravel which has cleared out quite a chunk of my confusion. It would be better if there's a beginner course here for the 'starter packs' offered in Laravel docs.

replies.body:
I don't have plans to do an Inertia version for Breeze/Jetstream but there should eventually be a general Inertia.js series here on Laracasts.

This series is exactly what you're describing. An overview of the "starter packs" for auth in Laravel. If you're still confused about some of the topics, maybe go back and re-visit some of those concepts. For example, a lot of people are not familiar with blade components and their syntax (there's a series on them here on Laracasts).

It might be Inertia that you're still not too familiar with. While you wait for the Inertia series, definitely check out their excellent documentation but more importantly the demo "Ping CRM" app they have. Install it locally then take a look at the code and Vue components they have to piece it all together.

It might be Inertia that you're still not too familiar with. While you wait for the Inertia series, definitely check out their excellent documentation but more importantly the demo "Ping CRM" app they have.
